title: Whistleblower reports DOGE exposed 300 million Americans' Social Security data
summary:
SSA Chief Data Officer Charles Borges filed a whistleblower complaint alleging DOGE
employees, including 19-year-old Ed "Big Balls" Coristine, created an unsecured copy
of the NUMIDENT database containing Social Security numbers, names, birthdates, and
citizenship data for 300+ million Americans on a vulnerable cloud server. SSA cybersecurity
officials called it "very high risk" and discussed possibly reissuing Social Security
numbers to all Americans if breached.

sources.title: Whistleblower says DOGE put Social Security numbers at risk
Social Security official says DOGE compromised Americans' data
DOGE put Americans' Social Security records at risk, whistleblower says

notes:
The NUMIDENT database includes all information from Social Security card applications.
On June 10, 2025, former DOGE employee John Solly requested the database copy to a
private cloud. Borges warned of potential widespread identity theft and loss of health
care and food benefits if breached. SSA claimed data remains secure.
